data.title: It Happened on this date
data.meta_description:
1637 â The contract prices of rare tulip bulbs in the Dutch Republic, which had been steadily climbing for three months, abruptly dropped, marking the decline of tulip mania.
 1807 â Napoleonic Wars: The United Kingdom captured Montevideo, now the capital of Uruguay, from the Spanish Empire.
 1813 â Argentine War of
data.text:
6th of November

Events

355 â Roman Emperor Constantius II promotes his cousin Julian to the rank of Caesar, entrusting him with the government of the Prefecture of the Gauls.

1528 â Shipwrecked Spanish conquistador Ãlvar NÃºÃ±ez Cabeza de Vaca becomes the first known European to set foot in Texas.

1632 â Thirty years war: Battle of LÃ¼tzen is fought, the Swedes are victorious but the King of Sweden, Gustavus Adolphus dies in the battle.

1789 â Pope Pius VI appoints Father John Carroll as the first Catholic bishop in the United States.

1844 â The first constitution of the Dominican Republic is adopted.

1856 â Scenes of Clerical Life, the first work of fiction by the author later known as George Eliot, is submitted for publication.

1861 â American Civil War: Jefferson Davis is elected president of the Confederate States of America.

1865 â American Civil War: CSS Shenandoah is the last Confederate combat unit to surrender after circumnavigating the globe on a cruise on which it sank or captured 37 unarmed merchant vessels.

1869 â In New Brunswick, New Jersey, Rutgers College defeats Princeton University (then known as the College of New Jersey), 6-4, in the first official intercollegiate American football game.

1913 â Mohandas Gandhi is arrested while leading a march of Indian miners in South Africa.

1917 â World War I: Third Battle of Ypres ends: After three months of fierce fighting, Canadian forces take Passchendaele in Belgium.

1918 â The Second Polish Republic is proclaimed.

1934 â Memphis, Tennessee becomes the first major city to join the Tennessee Valley Authority.

1935 â Edwin Armstrong presents his paper "A Method of Reducing Disturbances in Radio Signaling by a System of Frequency Modulation" to the New York section of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

1935 â First flight of the Hawker Hurricane.

1935 â Parker Brothers acquires the forerunner patents for MONOPOLY from Elizabeth Magie.

1939 â World War II: Sonderaktion Krakau takes place.

1941 â World War II: Soviet leader Joseph Stalin addresses the Soviet Union for only the second time during his three-decade rule. He states that even though 350,000 troops were killed in German attacks so far, the Germans had lost 4.5 million soldiers and that Soviet victory was near.

1942 â World War II: Carlson's patrol during the Guadalcanal Campaign begins.

1943 â World War II: the Soviet Red Army recaptures Kiev. Before withdrawing, the Germans destroy most of the city's ancient buildings.

1944 â Plutonium is first produced at the Hanford Atomic Facility and subsequently used in the Fat Man atomic bomb dropped on Nagasaki, Japan.

1947 â Meet the Press makes its television debut (the show went to a weekly schedule on September 12, 1948).

1948 â Deputy commander-in-chief of the Eastern China Field Army General Su Yu launched a massive offensive toward Xuzhou, defended by seven different armies under the Suppression General Headquarter of Xuzhou Garrison, the Huaihai Campaign, the largest operational campaign of the Chinese Civil War begins.

1962 â Apartheid: The United Nations General Assembly passes a resolution condemning South Africa's racist apartheid policies and calls for all UN member states to cease military and economic relations with the nation.

1963 â Vietnam War: Following the November 1 coup and execution of President Ngo Dinh Diem, coup leader General Duong Van Minh takes over leadership of South Vietnam.

1965 â Cuba and the United States formally agree to begin an airlift for Cubans who want to go to the United States. By 1971, 250,000 Cubans made use of this program.

1971 â The United States Atomic Energy Commission tests the largest U.S. underground hydrogen bomb, code-named Cannikin, on Amchitka Island in the Aleutians.

1975 â Green March begins: 300,000 unarmed Moroccans converge on the southern city of Tarfaya and wait for a signal from King Hassan II of Morocco to cross into Western Sahara.

1977 â The Kelly Barnes Dam, located above Toccoa Falls Bible College near Toccoa, Georgia, fails, killing 39.

1985 â In Colombia, leftist guerrillas of the 19th of April Movement seize control of the Palace of Justice in BogotÃ¡, eventually killing 115 people, 11 of them Supreme Court justices.

1986 â Sumburgh disaster â A British International Helicopters Boeing 234LR Chinook crashes 2.5 miles east of Sumburgh Airport killing 45 people. It is the deadliest civilian helicopter crash on record.

1991 â The last burning Kuwaiti oil field is extinguished.

1995 â The Rova of Antananarivo, home of the sovereigns of Madagascar from the 16th to 19th centuries, is destroyed by fire.

1995 â Cleveland Browns relocation controversy: Art Modell announces that he signed a deal that would relocate the Cleveland Browns to Baltimore to become the Baltimore Ravens, the first time the city had a football team since 1983 when they were the Baltimore Colts.

1999 â Australians vote to keep the Head of the Commonwealth as their head of state in the Australian republic referendum.

2004 â An express train collides with a stationary car near the village of Ufton Nervet, England, killing 7 and injuring 150. Wikipedia

7th of November

335 â Athanasius is banished to Trier, on charge that he prevented a grain fleet from sailing to Constantinople.

680 â The Sixth Ecumenical Council commences in Constantinople.

1492 â The Ensisheim meteorite, the oldest meteorite with a known date of impact, strikes the earth around noon in a wheat field outside the village of Ensisheim, Alsace, France.

1619 â Elizabeth of Scotland and England is crowned Queen of Bohemia.

1665 â The London Gazette, the oldest surviving journal, is first published.

1775 â John Murray, the Royal Governor of the Colony of Virginia, starts the first mass emancipation of slaves in North America by issuing Lord Dunmore's Offer of Emancipation, which offers freedom to slaves who abandoned their colonial masters in order to fight with Murray and the British.

1786 â The oldest musical organization in the United States is founded as the Stoughton Musical Society.

1811 â Tecumseh's War: The Battle of Tippecanoe is fought near present-day Battle Ground, Indiana, United States.

1837 â In Alton, Illinois, abolitionist printer Elijah P. Lovejoy is shot dead by a mob while attempting to protect his printing shop from being destroyed a third time.

1861 â American Civil War: Battle of Belmont: In Belmont, Missouri, Union forces led by General Ulysses S. Grant overrun a Confederate camp but are forced to retreat when Confederate reinforcements arrive.

1874 â A cartoon by Thomas Nast in Harper's Weekly, is considered the first important use of an elephant as a symbol for the United States Republican Party.

1885 â The completion of Canada's first transcontinental railway was symbolized by the Last Spike ceremony at Craigellachie, British Columbia.

1893 â Women's Suffrage: Women in the U.S. state of Colorado are granted the right to vote, the second state to do so.

1900 â Battle of Leliefontein, a battle during which the Royal Canadian Dragoons win three Victoria Crosses.

1907 â Delta Sigma Pi is founded at New York University.

1907 â JesÃºs GarcÃ­a saves the entire town of Nacozari de Garcia, Sonora by driving a burning train full of dynamite six kilometers () away before it can explode.

1908 â Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid are reportedly killed in San Vicente, Bolivia.

1910 â The first air freight shipment (from Dayton, Ohio, to Columbus, Ohio) is undertaken by the Wright Brothers and department store owner Max Moorehouse.

1912 â The Deutsche Opernhaus (now Deutsche Oper Berlin) opens in the Berlin neighborhood of Charlottenburg, with a production of Beethoven's Fidelio.

1914 â The first issue of The New Republic magazine is published.

1914 â The German colony of Kiaochow Bay and its centre at Tsingtao are captured by Japanese forces.

1916 â Jeannette Rankin is the first woman elected to the United States Congress.

1917 â The Gregorian calendar date of the October Revolution, which gets its name from the Julian calendar date of 25 October. On this date in 1917, the Bolsheviks storm the Winter Palace.

1917 â World War I: Third Battle of Gaza ends: British forces capture Gaza from the Ottoman Empire.

1918 â The 1918 influenza epidemic spreads to Western Samoa, killing 7,542 (about 20% of the population) by the end of the year.

1918 â Kurt Eisner overthrows the Wittelsbach dynasty in the Kingdom of Bavaria.

1919 â The first Palmer Raid is conducted on the second anniversary of the Russian Revolution. Over 10,000 suspected communists and anarchists are arrested in twenty-three different U.S. cities.

1920 â Patriarch Tikhon issues a decree that leads to the formation of the Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia.

1929 â In New York City, the Museum of Modern Art opens to the public.

1931 â The Chinese Soviet Republic is proclaimed on the anniversary of the October Revolution.

1933 â Fiorello H. La Guardia is elected the 99th mayor of New York City.

1940 â In Tacoma, Washington, the original Tacoma Narrows Bridge collapses in a windstorm, a mere four months after the bridge's completion.

1941 â World War II: Soviet hospital ship Armenia is sunk by German planes while evacuating refugees and wounded military and staff of several Crimean hospitals. It is estimated that over 5,000 people died in the sinking.

1944 â A passenger train derails in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico from excessive speed when descending a hill. 16 people are killed and 50 are injured.

1944 â Soviet spy Richard Sorge, a half-Russian, half-German World War I veteran, is hanged by his Japanese captors along with 34 of his ring.

1944 â Franklin D. Roosevelt elected for a record fourth term as President of the United States of America.

1949 â The first oil was taken in Oil Rocks (Neft Daşları), oldest offshore oil platform.

1956 â Suez Crisis: The United Nations General Assembly adopts a resolution calling for the United Kingdom, France and Israel to immediately withdraw their troops from Egypt.

1957 â Cold War: The Gaither Report calls for more American missiles and fallout shelters.

1963 â Wunder von Lengede: In Germany, eleven miners are rescued from a collapsed mine after 14 days.

1967 â Carl B. Stokes is elected as Mayor of Cleveland, Ohio, becoming the first African American mayor of a major American city.

1967 â US President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, establishing the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

1973 â The U.S. Congress overrides President Richard M. Nixon's veto of the War Powers Resolution, which limits presidential power to wage war without congressional approval.

1975 â In Bangladesh, a joint force of people and soldiers takes part in an uprising led by Col. Abu Taher that ousts and kills Brig. Khaled Mosharraf, freeing the then house-arrested army chief and future president Maj-Gen. Ziaur Rahman. The day is occasionally observed as the National Revolution and Solidarity Day.

1983 â 1983 United States Senate bombing: a bomb explodes inside the United States Capitol. No people are harmed, but an estimated $250,000 in damage is caused.

1987 â In Tunisia, president Habib Bourguiba is overthrown and replaced by Prime Minister Zine El Abidine Ben Ali.

1987 â Singapore's first Mass Rapid Transit line was opened, starting with train services between Yio Chu Kang and Toa Payoh stations.

1989 â Douglas Wilder wins the governor's seat in Virginia, becoming the first elected African American governor in the United States.

1989 â David Dinkins becomes the first African American to be elected mayor of New York City.

1989 â East German Prime Minister Willi Stoph, along with his entire cabinet, is forced to resign after huge anti-government protests.

1990 â Mary Robinson becomes the first woman to be elected President of the Republic of Ireland.

1991 â Magic Johnson announces that he is infected with HIV and retires from the NBA.

1994 â WXYC, the student radio station of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, provides the world's first internet radio broadcast.

1996 â NASA launches the Mars Global Surveyor.

2000 â Hillary Rodham Clinton is elected to the United States Senate, becoming the first former First Lady to win public office in the United States, although she was actually still the First Lady.

2000 â Controversial US presidential election that is later resolved in the Bush v. Gore Supreme Court Case.

2000 â The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration discovers one of the country's largest LSD labs inside a converted military missile silo in Wamego, Kansas.

2001 â SABENA, the national airline of Belgium, goes bankrupt.

2002 â Iran bans advertising of United States products.

2004 â War in Iraq: The interim government of Iraq calls for a 60-day "state of emergency" as U.S. forces storm the insurgent stronghold of Fallujah.

2007 â Jokela school shooting in Tuusula, Finland, resulting in the death of nine people.

2012 â An earthquake off the Pacific coast of Guatemala kills at least 52 people.

Wikipedia

8th of November

Events

960 â Battle of Andrassos: Byzantines under Leo Phokas the Younger score a crushing victory over the Hamdanid Emir of Aleppo, Sayf al-Dawla

1278 â Tran Thanh Tong, the second emperor of the Tran Dynasty, decide to pass the throne to his crown prince Tran Kham, take up the post of Retired Emperor.

1519 â HernÃ¡n CortÃ©s enters TenochtitlÃ¡n and Aztec ruler Moctezuma welcomes him with a great celebration.

1520 â Stockholm Bloodbath begins: A successful invasion of Sweden by Danish forces results in the execution of around 100 people.

1576 â Eighty Years' War: Pacification of Ghent â The States-General of the Netherlands meet and unite to oppose Spanish occupation.

1602 â The Bodleian Library at the University of Oxford is opened to the public.

1605 â Robert Catesby, ringleader of the Gunpowder Plotters, is killed.

1620 â The Battle of White Mountain takes place near Prague, ending in a decisive Catholic victory in only two hours.

1644 â The Shunzhi Emperor, the third emperor of the Qing Dynasty, is enthroned in Beijing after the collapse of the Ming Dynasty as the first Qing emperor to rule over China.

1745 â Charles Edward Stuart invades England with an army of ~5000 that would later participate in the Battle of Culloden.

1837 â Mary Lyon founds Mount Holyoke Female Seminary, which later becomes Mount Holyoke College.

1861 â American Civil War: The "Trent Affair" â The USS San Jacinto stops the British mail ship Trent and arrests two Confederate envoys, sparking a diplomatic crisis between the UK and US.

1889 â Montana is admitted as the 41st U.S. state.

1892 â The New Orleans general strike begins, uniting black and white American trade unionists in a successful four-day general strike action for the first time.

1895 â While experimenting with electricity, Wilhelm RÃ¶ntgen discovers the X-ray.

1898 â The Wilmington Insurrection of 1898, the only instance of an attempted coup d'etat in American history.

1901 â Bloody clashes take place in Athens following the translation of the Gospels into demotic Greek.

1917 â The People's Commissars give authority to Vladimir Lenin, Leon Trotsky, and Joseph Stalin.

1923 â Beer Hall Putsch: In Munich, Adolf Hitler leads the Nazis in an unsuccessful attempt to overthrow the German government.

1933 â Great Depression: New Deal â US President Franklin D. Roosevelt unveils the Civil Works Administration, an organization designed to create jobs for more than 4 million unemployed.

1936 â Spanish Civil War: Francoist troops fail in their effort to capture Madrid, but begin the 3-year Siege of Madrid afterwards.

1937 â The Nazi exhibition Der ewige Jude ("The Eternal Jew") opens in Munich.

1939 â Venlo Incident: Two British agents of SIS are captured by the Germans.

1939 â In Munich, Adolf Hitler narrowly escapes the assassination attempt of Georg Elser while celebrating the 16th anniversary of the Beer Hall Putsch.

1940 â Greco-Italian War: The Italian invasion of Greece fails as outnumbered Greek units repulse the Italians in the Battle of ElaiaâKalamas.

1942 â World War II: Operation Torch â United States and United Kingdom forces land in French North Africa.

1942 â World War II: French resistance coup in Algiers, in which 400 civilian French patriots neutralize Vichyist XIXth Army Corps after 15 hours of fighting, and arrest several Vichyst generals, allowing the immediate success of Operation Torch in Algiers.

1950 â Korean War: United States Air Force Lt. Russell J. Brown, while piloting an F-80 Shooting Star, shoots down two North Korean MiG-15s in the first jet aircraft-to-jet aircraft dogfight in history.

1957 â Operation Grapple X, Round C1: the United Kingdom conducts its first successful hydrogen bomb test over Kiritimati in the Pacific.

1960 â John F. Kennedy defeats Richard Nixon in one of the closest presidential elections of the twentieth century to become the 35th president of the United States.

1965 â The British Indian Ocean Territory is created, consisting of Chagos Archipelago, Aldabra, Farquhar and Des Roches islands.

1965 â The Murder (Abolition of Death Penalty) Act 1965 is given Royal Assent, formally abolishing the death penalty in the United Kingdom.

1965 â The 173rd Airborne is ambushed by over 1,200 Viet Cong in Operation Hump during the Vietnam War, while the 1st Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment fight one of the first set-piece engagements of the war between Australian forces and the Vietcong at the Battle of Gang Toi.

1966 â Former Massachusetts Attorney General Edward Brooke becomes the first African American elected to the United States Senate since Reconstruction.

1966 â U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson signs into law an antitrust exemption allowing the National Football League to merge with the upstart American Football League.

1968 â The Vienna Convention on Road Traffic is signed to facilitate international road traffic and to increase road safety by standardising the uniform traffic rules among the signatories.

1973 â The right ear of John Paul Getty III is delivered to a newspaper together with a ransom note, convincing his father to pay 2.9 million USD.

1976 â A series of earthquakes spreads panic in the city of Thessaloniki, which is evacuated.

1977 â Manolis Andronikos, a Greek archaeologist and professor at the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, discovers the tomb of Philip II of Macedon at Vergina.

1987 â Remembrance Day Bombing: A Provisional IRA bomb explodes in Enniskillen, Northern Ireland during a ceremony honouring those who had died in wars involving British forces. Twelve people are killed and sixty-three wounded.

2002 â Iraq disarmament crisis: UN Security Council Resolution 1441 â The United Nations Security Council unanimously approves a resolution on Iraq, forcing Saddam Hussein to disarm or face "serious consequences".

2004 â War in Iraq: More than 10,000 U.S. troops and a small number of Iraqi army units participate in a siege on the insurgent stronghold of Fallujah.

2011 â The potentially hazardous asteroid 2005 YU55 passed 0.85 lunar distances from Earth (about 324,600 kilometres or 201,700 miles), the closest known approach by an asteroid of its brightness since 2010 XC15 in 1976.

Wikipedia

9th of November

Events

694 â At the Seventeenth Council of Toledo, Egica, a king of the Visigoths of Hispania, accuses Jews of aiding Muslims, sentencing all Jews to slavery.

1282 â Pope Martin IV excommunicates King Peter III of Aragon.

1313 â Louis the Bavarian defeats his cousin Frederick I of Austria at the Battle of Gamelsdorf.

1330 â At the Battle of Posada, the Wallachian Voivode Basarab I defeats the Hungarian army of Charles I Robert.

1456 â Ulrich II of Celje (Slovene: Ulrik Celjski, German Ulrich von Cilli, Hungarian: Cillei Ulrik), last prince of Celje principality, is assassinated in Belgrade.

1494 â The Family de' Medici are expelled from Florence.

1520 â More than 50 people are sentenced and executed in the Stockholm Bloodbath

1620 â Pilgrims aboard the Mayflower sight land at Cape Cod, Massachusetts.

1688 â Glorious Revolution: William of Orange captures Exeter.

1697 â Pope Innocent XII founds the city of Cervia.

1720 â The synagogue of Yehudah he-Hasid is burned down by Arab creditors, leading to the expulsion of the Ashkenazim from Jerusalem.

1729 â Spain, France and Great Britain sign the Treaty of Seville.

1764 â Mary Campbell, a captive of the Lenape during the French and Indian War, is turned over to forces commanded by Colonel Henry Bouquet.

1780 â American Revolutionary War: In the Battle of Fishdam Ford a force of British and Loyalist troops fail in a surprise attack against the South Carolina Patriot militia under Brigadier General Thomas Sumter.

1791 â Foundation of the Dublin Society of United Irishmen.

1793 â William Carey reaches the Hooghly River.

1799 â Napoleon Bonaparte leads the coup d'Ã©tat of 18 Brumaire ending the Directory government, and becoming one of its three Consuls (Consulate Government).

1822 â The Action of 9 November 1822 between USS Alligator and a squadron of pirate schooners off the coast of Cuba.

1848 â Robert Blum, a German revolutionary, is executed in Vienna.

1851 â Kentucky marshals abduct abolitionist minister Calvin Fairbank from Jeffersonville, Indiana, and take him to Kentucky to stand trial for helping a slave escape.

1857 â The Atlantic is founded in Boston, Massachusetts.

1861 â The first documented football match in Canada is played at University College, University of Toronto.

1862 â American Civil War: Union General Ambrose Burnside assumes command of the Army of the Potomac, after George B. McClellan is removed.

1867 â Tokugawa Shogunate hands power back to the Emperor of Japan, starting the Meiji Restoration.

1872 â The Great Boston Fire of 1872.

1880 â A large earthquake strikes Zagreb and causes many casualties. One of them is the Zagreb Cathedral.

1883 â The Royal Winnipeg Rifles of the Canadian Forces (known then as the "90th Winnipeg Battalion of Rifles") is founded.

1887 â The United States receives rights to Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.

1888 â Mary Jane Kelly is murdered in London, widely believed to be the fifth and final victim of the notorious unidentified serial killer Jack the Ripper.

1906 â Theodore Roosevelt is the first sitting President of the United States to make an official trip outside the country. He did so to inspect progress on the Panama Canal.

1907 â The Cullinan Diamond is presented to King Edward VII on his birthday.

1913 â The Great Lakes Storm of 1913, the most destructive natural disaster ever to hit the lakes, destroys 19 ships and kills more than 250 people.

1914 â SMS Emden is sunk by HMAS Sydney in the Battle of Cocos.

1917 â Joseph Stalin enters the provisional government of Bolshevik Russia.

1918 â Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany abdicates after the German Revolution, and Germany is proclaimed a Republic.

1921 â The Partito Nazionale Fascista (PNF), National Fascist Party, comes into existence.

1923 â In Munich, Germany, police and government troops crush the Beer Hall Putsch in Bavaria. The failed coup is the work of the Nazis.

1935 â The Congress of Industrial Organizations is founded in Atlantic City, New Jersey, by eight trade unions belonging to the American Federation of Labor.

1937 â Japanese troops take control of Shanghai, China.

1938 â The Nazi German diplomat Ernst vom Rath dies from the fatal gunshot wounds of Jewish resistance fighter Herschel Grynszpan, an act which the Nazis used as an excuse to instigate the 1938 national pogrom, also known as Kristallnacht (Crystal Night).

1940 â Warsaw is awarded the Virtuti Militari.

1953 â Cambodia gains independence from France.

1960 â Robert McNamara is named president of Ford Motor Co., the first non-Ford to serve in that post. A month later, he resigned to join the administration of newly elected John F. Kennedy.

1963 â At Miike coal mine, Miike, Japan, an explosion kills 458, and hospitalises 839 with carbon monoxide poisoning.

1965 â Several U.S. states and parts of Canada are hit by a series of blackouts lasting up to 13 hours in the Northeast Blackout of 1965.

1965 â The Catholic Worker Movement member Roger Allen LaPorte, protesting against the Vietnam War, sets himself on fire in front of the United Nations building.

1967 â Apollo program: NASA launches the unmanned Apollo 4 test spacecraft atop the first Saturn V rocket from Cape Kennedy, Florida.

1967 â The first issue of Rolling Stone Magazine is published.

1970 â Vietnam War: The Supreme Court of the United States votes 6 to 3 against hearing a case to allow Massachusetts to enforce its law granting residents the right to refuse military service in an undeclared war.

1979 â Nuclear false alarm: the NORAD computers and the Alternate National Military Command Center in Fort Ritchie, Maryland detected purported massive Soviet nuclear strike. After reviewing the raw data from satellites and checking the early warning radars, the alert is cancelled.

1985 â Garry Kasparov, 22, of the Soviet Union becomes the youngest World Chess Champion by beating Anatoly Karpov, also of the Soviet Union.

1989 â Cold War: Fall of the Berlin Wall. Communist-controlled East Germany opens checkpoints in the Berlin Wall allowing its citizens to travel to West Germany. This key event led to the eventual reunification of East and West Germany, and fall of communism in eastern Europe including Russia.

1993 â Stari most, the "old bridge" in Bosnian Mostar built in 1566, collapses after several days of bombing.

1994 â The chemical element Darmstadtium is discovered.

1998 â A US federal judge orders 37 US brokerage houses to pay 1.03 billion USD to cheated NASDAQ investors to compensate for price-fixing. This is the largest civil settlement in United States history.

1998 â Capital punishment in the United Kingdom, already abolished for murder, is completely abolished for all remaining capital offences.

2005 â The Venus Express mission of the European Space Agency is launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.

2005 â Suicide bombers attacked three hotels in Amman, Jordan, killing at least 60 people.

2007 â The German Bundestag passes the controversial data retention bill mandating storage of citizens' telecommunications traffic data for six months without probable cause.

Wikipedia

10th of November

1202 â Fourth Crusade: Despite letters from Pope Innocent III forbidding it and threatening excommunication, Catholic crusaders begin a siege of the Catholic city of Zara (now Zadar, Croatia).

1293 â Raden Wijaya is crowned as the first monarch of Majapahit kingdom of Java, taking throne name Kertarajasa Jayawardhana.

1444 â Battle of Varna: The crusading forces of King Vladislaus III of Varna (aka Ulaszlo I of Hungary and Wladyslaw III of Poland) are crushed by the Turks under Sultan Murad II and Vladislaus is killed.

1520 â Danish King Christian II executes dozens of people in the Stockholm Bloodbath after a successful invasion of Sweden.

1580 â After a three-day siege, the English Army beheads over 600 Papal soldiers and civilians at DÃºn an Ãir, Ireland.

1619 â RenÃ© Descartes has the dreams that inspire his Meditations on First Philosophy.

1659 â Chattrapati Shivaji Maharaj, Maratha King kills Afzal Khan, Adilshahi in the battle popularly known as Battle of Pratapgarh. This is also recognised as the first defence of Swarajya

1674 â Anglo-Dutch War: As provided in the Treaty of Westminster, Netherlands cedes New Netherlands to England.

1702 â English colonists under the command of James Moore besiege Spanish St. Augustine during Queen Anne's War.

1766 â The last colonial governor of New Jersey, William Franklin, signs the charter of Queen's College (later renamed Rutgers University).

1775 â The United States Marine Corps is founded at Tun Tavern in Philadelphia by Samuel Nicholas.

1793 â A Goddess of Reason is proclaimed by the French Convention at the suggestion of Chaumette.

1821 â Cry of Independence by Rufina Alfaro at La Villa de Los Santos, Panama setting into motion a revolt which lead to Panama's independence from Spain and to it immediately becoming part of Colombia

1847 â The passenger ship Stephen Whitney is wrecked in thick fog off the southern coast of Ireland, killing 92 of the 110 on board. The disaster results in the construction of the Fastnet Rock lighthouse.

1865 â Major Henry Wirz, the superintendent of a prison camp in Andersonville, Georgia, is hanged, becoming the only American Civil War soldier executed for war crimes.

1871 â Henry Morton Stanley locates missing explorer and missionary, Dr. David Livingstone in Ujiji, near Lake Tanganyika, famously greeting him with the words, "Dr. Livingstone, I presume?".

1898 â Beginning of the Wilmington Insurrection of 1898, the only instance of a municipal government being overthrown in US history.

1910 â The date of Thomas A. Davis' opening of the San Diego Army and Navy Academy, though the official founding date is November 23, 1910.

1918 â The Western Union Cable Office in North Sydney, Nova Scotia, receives a top-secret coded message from Europe (that would be sent to Ottawa, Ontario, and Washington, DC) that said on November 11, 1918, all fighting would cease on land, sea and in the air.

1919 â The first national convention of the American Legion is held in Minneapolis, Minnesota, ending on November 12.

1940 â The 1940 Vrancea earthquake strikes Romania killing an estimated 1,000 and injuring approximately 4,000 more.

1942 â World War II: Germany invades Vichy France following French Admiral FranÃ§ois Darlan's agreement to an armistice with the Allies in North Africa.

1944 â The ammunition ship USS Mount Hood explodes at Seeadler Harbour, Manus, Admiralty Islands, killing at least 432 and wounding 371.

1945 â Heavy fighting in Surabaya between Indonesian nationalists and returning colonialists after World War II, today celebrated as Heroes' Day (Hari Pahlawan).

1951 â Direct-dial coast-to-coast telephone service begins in the United States.

1954 â U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower dedicates the USMC War Memorial (Iwo Jima memorial) in Arlington National Cemetery.

1958 â The Hope Diamond is donated to the Smithsonian Institution by New York diamond merchant Harry Winston.

1969 â National Educational Television (the predecessor to the Public Broadcasting Service) in the United States debuts the children's television program Sesame Street.

1970 â Vietnam War: Vietnamization â For the first time in five years, an entire week ends with no reports of American combat fatalities in Southeast Asia.

1970 â The Soviet Lunar probe Lunokhod 1 is launched.

1971 â In Cambodia, Khmer Rouge forces attack the city of Phnom Penh and its airport, killing 44, wounding at least 30 and damaging nine aircraft.

1972 â Southern Airways Flight 49 from Birmingham, Alabama is hijacked and, at one point, is threatened with crashing into the nuclear installation at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory. After two days, the plane lands in Havana, Cuba, where the hijackers are jailed by Fidel Castro.

1975 â The 729-foot-long freighter SS Edmund Fitzgerald sinks during a storm on Lake Superior, killing all 29 crew on board.

1975 â United Nations Resolution 3379: United Nations General Assembly approves a resolution equating Zionism with racism (the resolution is repealed in December 1991 by Resolution 4686).

1979 â A 106-car Canadian Pacific freight train carrying explosive and poisonous chemicals from Windsor, Ontario, Canada derails in Mississauga, Ontario, Canada just west of Toronto, Ontario, Canada, causing a massive explosion and the largest peacetime evacuation in Canadian history and one of the largest in North American history.

1984 â The first Breeders' Cup takes place at Hollywood Park Racetrack.
